results.headline: Love Triangle Bound by Tape and Talk

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Serious Moonlight

results.summary_short: “Serious Moonlight” suggests an unholy, watered-down hybrid of “The Ref” and “Funny Games,” played as a chirpy screwball comedy.

results.headline: A Tale of India

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paa

results.summary_short: “Paa” has a weird I’m-my-own-grandpa charge.

results.headline: College Humor on the Big Screen

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mystery Team

results.summary_short: “Mystery Team” runs up against the hazard that confronts all sketch comedy: Can an idea that works for 5 minutes be sustained for more than 100?

results.headline: Love (Bashful) in the Nighttime Workplace (Oppressive)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gigante

results.summary_short: “Gigante” is a small, unpretentious slice of Uruguayan neo-realism.

results.headline: De Niro Packs His Suitcase, Heading to Geezer Territory

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Everybody's Fine

results.summary_short: Warning: A putatively heartwarming dramatic comedy like “Everybody’s Fine” can be hazardous to your health.

results.headline: A War Abroad Ignites a Battle at Home

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Brothers

results.summary_short: “Brothers” is in some ways less a movie about war than a movie that uses war as a scaffolding for domestic melodrama.

results.headline: A Lawyer With a Tragic Past and Future

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Breaking Point

results.summary_short: After a particularly brutal, attention-grabbing start, “Breaking Point” quickly devolves into a flavorless stew of murder, corruption, blackmail and baby tossing.

results.headline: In Old Clips, a Paradise Found and Lost
results.display_title: Film ist a Girl & a Gun

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Film ist a Girl & a Gun

results.summary_short: The Austrian director Gustav Deutsch constructs “Film Ist. a Girl & a Gun” from a wealth of found footage borrowed from film archives from around the world.

results.headline: Ancient Inuit Wisdom as Sustenance in Dire Times

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Before Tomorrow

results.summary_short: “Before Tomorrow” succumbs to ethnographic sentimentality in its idyllic depiction of a world threatened by evil.

results.headline: In a Wife’s Crème Brûlée, Visions of a Stormy Past
results.display_title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Private Lives of Pippa Lee

results.summary_short: Rebecca Miller’s fourth film is a wry, acutely observant drama.

results.headline: Longing for the Old Days and Looking for Meaning

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ward No. 6

results.summary_short: “Ward No. 6” is an updated adaptation of Chekhov’s famous short story set in a Russian provincial mental hospital.

results.headline: An Isolated Family Hears Outside World Knocking

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Home

results.summary_short: “Home” is an art-house domestic comedy with a tragic undercurrent about a family and its idiosyncratic cohabitation.

results.headline: When a Bombastic Young Man Bestrode the Boards of the Mercury Theater

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Me and Orson Welles

results.summary_short: “Me and Orson Welles” pays tribute to youthful creative ambition where and whenever it may thrive.

results.headline: Father and Son Bond in Gloomy Aftermath of Disaster

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Road

results.summary_short: The most arresting aspect of “The Road” is just how fully the filmmakers have realized this bleak, blighted landscape of a modern society reduced to savagery.

results.headline: Hero Who Can’t Keep His Shirt On

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ninja Assassin

results.summary_short: The best thing about “Ninja Assassin” is its refreshingly honest title.

results.headline: That Old Bayou Magic: Kiss and Ribbit (and Sing)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Princess and the Frog

results.summary_short: It’s not easy being green. But to judge from how this hand-drawn movie addresses, or rather strenuously avoids, race, it is a lot more difficult to be black.

results.headline: A Bit Mangy, but Up for New Tricks

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Old Dogs

results.summary_short: To describe the knockabout family comedy “Old Dogs” as a ramshackle mess doesn’t begin to evoke the confusion and sloppy continuity of the movie.

results.headline: Almodóvar’s Happy Agony, Swirling Amid Jealousy and Revenge

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Broken Embraces

results.summary_short: Can there be such a thing as exuberant melancholy? I can’t think of another way to describe the spirit of “Broken Embraces.”

results.headline: Abstinence Makes the Heart ... Oh, You Know

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Twilight Saga:  New Moon

results.summary_short: The big tease turns into the long goodbye in “The Twilight Saga: New Moon.”

results.headline: Gazing Longingly at Manhattan

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Staten Island

results.summary_short: If “Staten Island, New York” is an ode to what it calls “the forgotten stepchild of Manhattan,” it is a barbed and quirky one.
